summary: This is an FBI daily briefing from November 13, 2020, covering a wide range of national security, criminal, and political news. The most significant Epstein-related item is a summary of a DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility report concluding that former U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta exercised 'poor judgment' but did not engage in professional misconduct when agreeing to Jeffrey Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution plea deal. The briefing also covers election security, COVID-19, various criminal investigations, and international news.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, former U.S. Secretary of Labor
persons.context: Subject of a DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility report regarding his handling of the 2008 Jeffrey Epstein plea deal. The report found he exercised 'poor judgment' but no professional misconduct.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of the 2008 non-prosecution plea deal orchestrated by Alex Acosta, which allowed him to avoid federal sex trafficking charges.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.context: Criticized the DOJ report on Acosta, stating letting Epstein 'get away with child rape and international sex trafficking' was a 'disgusting failure,' not just poor judgment.

persons.name: Adam Horowitz
persons.context: Criticized the DOJ report on Acosta, calling the mistakes 'reckless' and not merely poor judgment.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, negotiated the 2008 non-prosecution agreement that allowed Epstein to plead guilty to state charges and avoid federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta agreed to a non-prosecution deal with Jeffrey Epstein, allowing him to plead guilty to state prostitution charges and avoid federal sex trafficking charges, despite allegations of abusing dozens of underage girls.

events.title: DOJ Releases Report on Acosta's Conduct
events.description: The Justice Department's Office of Professional Responsibility released a report concluding Alex Acosta used 'poor judgment' in the Epstein case but did not commit professional misconduct. The report was criticized by victims' lawyers and Senator Ben Sasse.

keyFacts: The DOJ's internal review found former U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta showed 'poor judgment' but no professional misconduct in his handling of the 2008 Jeffrey Epstein plea deal.
The report concluded Acosta failed to ensure victims were notified about the state plea hearing as part of the agreement.
Senator Ben Sasse and attorneys for Epstein's victims strongly criticized the DOJ report's findings.
The 2008 deal allowed Epstein to plead guilty to state charges and serve 13 months, largely in a work-release program, avoiding federal sex trafficking charges.
